authors.name: Valeria Jimenez
authors.affiliation: CNRS, Sorbonne Université, Station Biologique de Roscoff, France

description: {"blocks":[{"key":"64o8r","text":"This methodology describes a protocol modified from Sherr and Sherr (1993) to determine phytoplankton prey uptake using flow cytometry and yellow-green fluorescent polystyrene-based microspheres (YG-beads; 0.5 µm in diameter,  Fluoresbrite, Polysciences, Inc., Warrington, PA, USA) or fluorescently labelled bacteria (FLBs) as food proxies. FLBs were prepared according to the protocol of Sherr et al. (1987) using the bacteria Brevundimonas diminuta (strain CECT313, also named Pseudomonas diminuta), obtained from the Spanish Type Culture Collection (CECT, Valencia, Spain). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":395,"length":5},{"style":"italic","offset":428,"length":22},{"style":"italic","offset":479,"length":20}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"balg1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dmbr2","text":"The percent of cells with prey were measured in the laboratory in four Micromonas polaris strains and one mixotrophic strain (Ochromonas triangulata) used as a positive control. The percent of cells with beads was determined in samples fixed with Lugol's iodine solution (protocol explained in detail here) and enumerated with a flow cytometer (Guava easyCyte, Luminex Corporation, USA) where cells that contained chlorophyll as well as green fluorescence (same signal as the prey added, YG-beads or FLBs) were considered to be cells containing prey (quantification protocol explain in detail here). To determine the uptake of prey over time the percent of cells with preys was quantified in each experimental flask by first adding preys and then sub-sampling and fixing after an incubation of 0 (T0), 20 (T20) and 40 (T40) minutes. The T0 sample accounts for the physical attachment of preys to the cell and therefore the percent of cells ingesting prey corresponds to the percent of cells with prey at T20 or T40, minus the percent of cells with prey at T0.  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":71,"length":18},{"style":"italic","offset":126,"length":22}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"fqrjl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"64k7l","text":"References:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":10},{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"71ur5","text":"Sherr, EB. \u0026 Sherr, BF. (1993). Protistan grazing rates via uptake of fluorescently labeled prey. In Kemp, P., Sherr, B., Sherr, E. \u0026 Cole, J. (eds.) Handbook of Methods in Aquatic Microbial Ecology, 695–701 (Lewis Publishers: Boca Raton, USA).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3ophg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"d83l3","text":"Sherr, EB., Sherr, BF. \u0026 Fallon, RD. (1987). Use of monodispersed, fluorescently labeled bacteria to estimate in situ protozoan bacterivory. Appl Environ Microbiol.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2sji3","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

fork_info.title: Mixotrophy - Quantification of the percent of phytoplankton cells with preys (e.g. fluorescent microspheres or fluorescently labeled bacteria)

materials.name: Fluorescent Microsphere (polystyrene-based latex particles): Fluoresbrite Yellow-Green Microspheres. 0.50 μm diameter of particles, with excitation maxima of 441nm and emission maxima at 485 nm
Acid Lugol’s solution (see fixatives preparation section)
Fluorescently labeled bacteria (FLBs); prepared according to protocol of Sherr et al. (1987)

status.info: We use this protocol and it's working

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"8j4lm","text":"Prepare your prey (YG-beads or FLBs) stock solution. Vortex vigorously and sonicate the solution for ~60 seconds. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"duh2p","text":"Take the phytoplankton flasks under different culture conditions (e.g. phytoplankton incubated in the dark and under nutrient limitation) on which to test uptake of prey (use at least 2 to 3 replicates per phytoplankton strain and culture condition) ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1krtl","text":"Add the preys to each flask (one flask at a time). After microsphere addition, gently mix the flask to evenly distribute microspheres and then take a sub-sample from the flask for immediate fixation (see fixation protocol section). This sub-sample is the T0 for background correction (attachment of preys to cells not associated with mixotrophy)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"49u46","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"botk9","text":"Preys (Microspheres or FLBs) added to attain a preys to cells ratio of 1 to 2.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"fhdff","text":"The addition of preys and subsequent fixation can be done in the same culture flask (sacrifice culture) or by taking an aliquot (e.g. 5 ml) into a culture tube or scintillation vials. The following protocol is written using culture flasks.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8gst4","text":"After the addition of preys and the sampling and fixation of the T0 sample, each flask with preys can be sampled and fixed over time (After 20 (T20) and 40 (T40) minutes incubation with preys) as performed with T0 sample.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9d3mi","text":"After all flasks and time points are fixed, samples are kept on ice are in the dark to be run in the flow cytometer the same day.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Quantification of the percent of cells with preys using a flow cytometer
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"ca8g7","text":"After all flasks and time points are fixed, samples are run in the flow cytometer the same day.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Quantification of the percent of cells with preys using a flow cytometer
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"1fah4","text":"To determine the percent of cells with preys the sample is run with the threshold on red fluorescence. Cells without preys only show red autofluorescence from chlorophyll and the cells with the same chlorophyll fluorescence as well as green fluorescence (same signal as the prey added, YG-beads or FLBs) are considered to be cells containing prey.  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"62tju","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5tg9s","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"f5tre","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Quantification of the percent of cells with preys using a flow cytometer
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"8l654","text":"In addition, to confirm the total concentration of prey added to each flask, the sample was also run with the threshold on green fluorescence","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Quantification of the percent of cells with preys using a flow cytometer
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"l4v4","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"afal7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"A1876D007E7211EA994937629A638F01","height":813,"id":353748,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":18,"offset":56,"style":"italic"},{"length":22,"offset":100,"style":"italic"}],"key":"4njht","text":"Figure of dot plots examples of flow cytometry data for Micromonas polaris and the positive control Ochromonas triangulata. Cells that display red autofluorescence from chlorophyll and green fluorescence are considered as cells containing prey (cells with YG-beads in green, cells with FLBs in orange and cells without prey in blue). In addition, to confirm the total concentration of prey added to each experimental flask, the same sample was also run with the threshold on green fluorescence (only YG-beads and FLBs in grey and black respectively)","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":[]},"mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"SuppFig_Histograms_Micromonas_Feeding_exp_MS_12Mar20.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/public/a7c152c9c54af26a11b594389a478e2921c5d718bd1c909178b8615e089231d0/b5jwiuue.png","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/k3qwiuue.jpg","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/k3qviuue.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8o72s","text":"The following fixation protocol must be done under a hood.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"40j6o","text":"The volume of reagents must be added to 5 ml of culture.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"40lv5","text":"Add 50 µl of acid Lugol’s iodine solution (see fixatives preparation section) to the sample.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"b7ehm","text":"Add 50 µl 3% Thiosulfate (see fixatives preparation section) to the sample.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8puqa","text":"Make sure the sample is thoroughly cleared of Lugol’s stain, if not add more sodium thiosulfate until it is clear (e.g. another 50 µl)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"8a192","text":"Dissolve 10 g of Potassium iodide in 100 ml distilled water","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"8h2fo","text":"Slowly add 5 g of iodine crystals. Shake to dissolve.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"1d9pm","text":"Add 10 ml glacial acetic acid. Store in the dark.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Fixatives preparation: Sodium Thiosulfate at 3% weight/volume
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"5q2u","text":"Add 3 ml of sodium thiosulfate in 97 ml of distilled water","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}
